The render-graphs.js utility uses standard Node.js file operations for diagram rendering. No malicious intent or security vulnerabilities present.

content.value_statement: Writing skills helps you build reusable, tested documentation that Claude can discover and apply. This skill adapts test-driven development to process documentation, ensuring your skills actually work when agents need them.
actual_capabilities: Create skills following test-driven development methodology
Write skills that resist rationalization under pressure
Structure documentation for optimal Claude discovery
Test skills with subagents before deployment
Apply persuasion principles for effective skill design
Organize skill files and cross-references properly
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly
Requires understanding of test-driven development fundamentals
Does not generate skills automatically - guides the writing process

use_cases.title: Build Production Skills
use_cases.description: Create skills that are tested, documented, and ready for deployment with real usage scenarios.

use_cases.title: Structure Reference Docs
use_cases.description: Write reference documentation that Claude can discover and apply effectively at the right moments.

use_cases.title: Enforce Team Practices
use_cases.description: Create discipline-enforcing skills that ensure processes are followed even under time pressure.

prompt_templates.title: New Skill Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a new skill for [purpose]. Walk me through the TDD cycle - first show me how to write a failing baseline test, then help me write the skill documentation.

prompt_templates.title: Skill Testing
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to test my [skill-name] skill. Show me how to create pressure scenarios that expose rationalizations, then help me close the loopholes.

prompt_templates.title: Documentation Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: My skill [skill-name] is not being discovered by Claude. Review my SKILL.md and suggest improvements to the description, keywords, and structure for better CSO.

prompt_templates.title: Cross-Referencing
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create cross-references between my [skill-a] and [skill-b] skills. Show me the proper format for referencing required sub-skills.

output_examples.input: How do I test if my new skill actually works?
output: Run the TDD cycle: First test WITHOUT the skill to capture baseline behavior
Create 3+ combined pressure scenarios (time pressure, sunk cost, exhaustion)
Document exact rationalizations the agent uses when skipping the skill
Write the skill addressing those specific failures
Re-test WITH the skill - agent should now comply

output_examples.input: What makes a good skill description?
output: Start with 'Use when...' - describe triggering conditions, not workflow
Include specific symptoms and situations that signal the skill applies
Write in third person for system prompt injection
Keep triggers technology-agnostic unless the skill is technology-specific
NEVER summarize the skill's process or workflow

output_examples.input: How do I stop agents from rationalizing around my discipline-enforcing skill?
output: Close every loophole explicitly - forbid specific workarounds
Add 'No exceptions' statements with concrete examples
Address spirit vs letter arguments with foundational principles
Build a rationalization table from actual test failures
Create a red flags list for self-checking

best_practices: Always test skills with subagents before deployment - never skip the baseline failure phase
Write descriptions that describe WHEN to use, not WHAT the skill does
Use concrete examples from real scenarios, not generic templates
anti_patterns: Writing skills without testing - untested skills have undetected gaps
Summarizing workflow in descriptions - Claude may follow description instead of reading the full skill
Including multiple language examples - one excellent example is better than mediocre examples in 5 languages

faq.question: What is the difference between a technique, pattern, and reference skill?
faq.answer: Techniques are concrete step-by-step methods. Patterns are mental models for thinking about problems. References are API docs or tool documentation.

faq.question: How long should my SKILL.md be?
faq.answer: Getting-started workflows under 150 words. Frequently-loaded skills under 200 words. Other skills under 500 words. Be concise.

faq.question: When should I create a separate supporting file?
faq.answer: Only when reference material exceeds 100 lines or when you have reusable code tools. Keep everything else inline.

faq.question: How do I name my skill?
faq.answer: Use active voice with verb-first format: creating-skills not skill-creation. Use hyphens, not underscores or spaces.

faq.question: What makes a good code example in a skill?
faq.answer: One excellent example from a real scenario that is complete, runnable, and shows the pattern clearly. Ready to adapt.

faq.question: How do I cross-reference other skills properly?
faq.answer: Use skill name only with explicit markers: REQUIRED SUB-SKILL or REQUIRED BACKGROUND. Avoid @ syntax that force-loads files.
